data: Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia
Giacomo Manganaro, «Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia», Epigraphica 51 (1989): 161–96

Horizontal guidelines between lines, but almost no interlineation. The text maintains left and right margins (with guideline indicating an outer right margin), with words broken across lines or abbreviated to maintain the margins. Interpuncts mark the ends of lines 2 and 3.
Tall narrow letters with pronounced serifs and curved horizontal feet to vertical strokes.

Funerary inscription for Gaius Popillius Priscus

Eight lines of Latin text, in centre (but not centred) of stone. Use of triangular interpuncts, although some are faint and indistinct. Interpuncts are not used between every word. Line 1 is notably larger, line 2 reduces, the other lines much smaller.

Tall, elongated letters. Serifs used on many of the letters. First line is chiselled deeper into stone than subsequent ones. After line three, letter forms begin to lean to the left and become irregular.

The dating is contested by Bivona (later C1 CE, post-69) and Manganaro (a date shortly after 310-313 CE), based upon the reading of the word after 'Victoria' in line 4 (Bivona prefers Ticiniana, Manganaro Licininia). The other features of the text would seem to favour a later first rather than a fourth-century date.

Letter of Iulius Paternus to the Emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus

Latin text preserved over 12 lines. The first line is in slightly larger and more widely spaced letters. The text closes up over lines 2 and 3, 
                                    with a more or less regular size and spacing over the rest of the stone. Interpuncts are used sparingly in the text, and their placing appears 
                                    deliberately intended to emphasise certain elements. The letters are neatly cut, with limited serifs (but sometimes substantial feet to vertical strokes), 
                                    and a tendency towards the taller narrower letters common from the second/third centuries AD onwards; this is particularly noticeable with 
                                    the letter E, which is not always easy to distinguish when corroded. Tall 'I' is employed. P is generally open.
164—166 CE, on basis of restoration of first word as Armeniacis when Aurelius and Verus both held this title

fragmentary monumental latin inscription from the amphitheatre
1[---] Betilie[nus ---]

Five lines of Latin text, in straight alignment and shifted toward the right, with a wider left margin.The letters in the first line, which is partially legible, are of slightly greater module than those in the following lines, and are more widely spaced. The last line – of which only parts of one or more letters are preserved (perhaps an A and and the left apex of a V; an M is also possible) are preserved – appears more centered, with both left and right margins wider.

Elegant square capital letters, slightly verticalized, with serifs. The O in l. 1 is square in shape compared to the O in the other lines; A has a vertical crossbar, P has an open loop. In l. 2, a triple nexus links the letters T, R, and I, with the I rising above. In l. 4, there is spacing between the words Sosius and Priscus. Comma-shaped punctuation marks appear in ll. 1 and 3. A damaged ivy leaf appears at the end of l. 1.
Early 2nd century, mother of cos. 108 CE

Honorific inscription for Sextus Pompeius Priscus

Three lines of Latin text in straight alignment. Line 1 has a larger module than Line 2, and Line 2 has a larger module than Line 3. Furthermore, the lack of space in the final line resulted in a greater compression between the letters compared to the other lines.

Elegant square capital letters, slightly verticalized, with serifs. P has an open loop; O and Q are ovoid; A has a vertical crossbar. Spacing in line 2 between the words Quir(ina) and Prisc[o]. A comma-shaped punctuation mark appears in line 1, between Q(uinto) and Pompeio.

Four lines of Latin text, in straight alignment. The letters in the first two lines are of larger module than those in the other lines. The letters of l. 3 appear narrower and more compressed than the others. The inscribed field is bordered by a moulded frame. In the lower part, decorative elements are visible, including a strip or handle, and a small vessel.
Elegant capital letters with slight serifs. P with open loop; A with vertical crossbar. Traces of interpuncts between words.

Funerary epitaph for Publius Scribonius Sollemnis

Multiple sets of guidelines are visible on the upper 2/3 of the face, which do not obviously correlate wiht the inscription, and which include a trace at the start of line 2 which belongs either to a false start or possibly an earlier text.
Fine v-cut monumental letters, with a medium width module, tending to curved and narrow. Pronounced serifs. Triangular interpunct end of line 3 after the name, but plain interpuncts in line 4.

Four lines of Latin letters, with vacat below; the trace of a letter below line 3 respects the exact distances between the other lines. Text runs at a slightly offset angle to the two edges.
Thin v-cut with neat serfis, use of supralines, ligatures, and a fairly narrow module. Very regular letters in height. G has a detached hook.
Letter types, esp. the G, sugg. c. 200 CE (so Manganaro; Ferrua dates later)

Manganaro suggests the letters are of 'stile tardo'

1[---]ORD[---]
2[---]CCCCTC[---]
3[---]ḄIISSS[---]

Irregular letters, some of which are larger than the others (the Latin D, the Greek Β). In the Greek text, E, Θ (according to Ferrua's drawing), Ω are lunate, (Latin and Greek), A has a broken cross-bar, Ξ is cursive. 
                                From Ferrua's drawing, the abbreviation of ὑπατίᾳ is realized through a small superscript π above the υ.
The Greek inscription has the consular date of 455 CE. If, as Manganaro believes, the two inscriptions are not the Latin and the Greek version of the same epitaph, they are nevertheless contemporary.
Manganaro, 1993, Greco nei pagi e latino nelle città della Sicilia romana tra I e VI sec. d.C.

Two lines of monumental letters, almost no spacing between the lines, with guidelines visible across the top of line 1.
The letters appear to be cut in a deep wide square cut, with a flat base to the cut; large rhomboid shaped interpunct line 2.
Manganaro argues for c.36 BC in specific context of the civil war; a civil war or Augustan date more generally is plausible.

Base recording construction by a C. Roscius and a Sextia
Four lines of Latin letters, steadily decreasing in height, with lines 1 and 3 set to the left margin, and lines 2 and 4 indented by one letter.

Elegantly carved letters in a fine v-cut, simple serifs, and a broad / square module (O, C, M all very wide), R with an elegant extended tail, P open, M with four full length strokes all off vertical.

Fragment of a dedication to a Roman emperor

The first line is set to the left, with lines 2 and 3 indented by 1.5 letter spaces. The text reduces in size in line 3, and the gap visible below line 3 (up to 32 mm)  is greater than the normal interlineation. Guidelines are visible in lines 2-3, but the letters do not appear to follow them.

Elegant well-spaced quite wide letters with a thin v-cut and pronounced curving serifs on almost all terminations. Letters tend to curvature (e.g. bottom stroke of E, the hook of the G, the tail of the R).P and R are open, G is rounded.  Interpunct not visible in line 1.
116 CE if Manganaro's restoration is accepted, but the potential attributions range through to the following century
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2016-10-10
fragment of a dedication to a roman emperor

The text is engraved in a single line across the middle of the three vertical surfaces on the front face of the stone.

Tall, narrow and slightly uneven, v-cut letters with some use of serifs; diminishing in height towards line end. A has a cross-bar which extends beyond the uprights on both sides, sloping down to the left; E has strokes of approximately equal length; P and R are open; S has larger upper half.
The formula perpetuus Augustus is typical of the fourth century

Larve vacat at top and to left, with three lines of Latin text preserved (the third broken below), of which the second line significantly indented below the first. The text shows signs of decreasing in size and becoming more compressed by line 3.
Very regular and neat Latin letters with simple straight line serifs on terminal and thin v-cut. Interpuncts in the form of a hollow triangle.

Funerary honours for Aulus Mevius Zethus
Two lines of Latin text filling the available field. The second line is slightly indented (and so centred?).

Neatly engraved and well proportioned letters with modest serifs. M has hastae slightly off vertical; E has bars of equal length; Z has long and curving horizontal strokes; the third T in line 2 is extended above the line. Words are separated by comma-like triangular interpuncts which find frequent parallels in the inscriptions of Halaesa.
2nd century CE, if Manganaro's link with  is accepted.
Facella, 2006, Alesa Arconidea: ricerche su un'antica città della Sicilia tirrenica
Prestianni Giallombardo, 2012, Spazio pubblico e memoria civica. Le epigrafi dall'agora di Alesa
Prag and Tigano, 2017, Alesa Archonidea: il lapidarium

Dedication by a sevir to Concordia
The epigraphic face is preserved for a width of 12.5 cm, with two lines of Latin letters filling the available field.

The letters are tall, neatly cut and closely spaced (height c.30mm), and words are separated by simple triangular interpuncts. The letters are lightly serifed. E is tall and narrow, T has a curved cross-bar, rising to the right.
Late 1st century CE, or 2nd century CE

Honours for L. Naevius(?) Firminus Manilianus
Remains of four lines of latin text are preserved: only the lower part of the first line survives, and only traces of the tops of letters remain from the beginning of line four.

The letters are V-cut and generously (and sometimes unevenly) spaced, with moderate serifs. R is closed, and both A and R have lightly cut horizontals; all the strokes of M are off-vertical. Words are separated by comma-like interpuncts.
2nd century CE or early 3rd century CE
Photo J. Prag courtesy Soprintendenza BBCCAA di Messina

1Ḷ(ucio) · Na[ev]ịo · Ḷ(uci) ·
2f(ilio) · Rom(ilia tribu) · Firmi-
3no · M[a]niḷiano
4..[. 8.]
The first part of all six lines of the Greek text are preserved, but none are complete.

The letters are uniform and well cut, with pronounced serifs. A hollow triangular interpunct is used between all the onomastic elements (but apparently not elsewhere in the text; spaces are however observed between words, with or without interpunct). Theta has a detached middle bar; omicron is full size; epsilon has a detached short middle bar; mu reaches almost to the lower line in the middle, and the outer strokes are vertical.
Moretti, 1986-1987, Per la storia di Halaesa in Sicilia
Campagna, 2007, Architettura pubblica ed evergetismo nella Sicilia di età repubblicana

5[--- quaest]ori · Au[gusti ---]
[---]
The text is laid out in a single column, with a consistent left margin, with every second line indented by c.1 letter; the right margin is irregular.

Letters are plainly cut with minimal serifs and a square module. Alpha has straight bar; beta has equal closed loops; epsilon sometimes has equal length strokes, sometimes shorter middle bar; theta is full size, slightly elliptical, with plain cross-bar; kappa has full length arms; mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes only half-descending; pi has overlapping horizontal, equal length vertical strokes; rho has closed eye of moderate size; sigma has horizontal upper and lower strokes; phi has an ovoid eye of varying size and extended vertical; omega varies between teardrop, rhomboid and small circle, always closed with horizontal baseline.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-05-10.
